text: hey guys Thomas Joseph here and for
today's kitchen conundrum were answering
one of your questions you've been asking
a lot about bread and how to get that
crisp exterior crust it's much easier
than you think it is actually minimal
effort but the one thing you do need is
a little bit of time so today I'm going
to show you how to make this delicious
no need bread
it has a chewy interior texture and a
great crunchy crust on the outside and
most people these days are buying bread
in the supermarket and it kind of looks
like this it's soft it doesn't have that
wonderful crunchy crust and today I'm
going to show you how to do it I have in
this bowl here three cups of bread flour
now bread flour is important here as
opposed to all-purpose flour because
bread flour has a higher amount of
protein in it so bread flour can go
anywhere from 11 to 13 percent protein
and that's what you need to create the
wonderful chewy structure that you get
in a bread like this so 3 cups of that I
need 1 teaspoon of fine sea salt here to
this add 3/4 of a teaspoon of active dry
yeast and now today I'm making an olive
and cheese bread I'm using 1 in 3/4 cups
of sliced green olives and they're
sliced about 1/4 of an inch thick here
just sprinkle that right in to your
flour mixture and 8 ounces of Greer
cheese this is an Alpine cheese it has a
really pungent wonderful flavor
now you could change up the cheese here
or you could even omit it change it up
with whatever ingredients you like this
is a basic formula and method and you
can really expand on it and play around
with this method so just stir these
things together add one and a half cups
of cool water now when I say cool that
means between 55 degrees and 65 degrees
because this is a slow rise so the
cooler the water temperature the less of
an effect it will have on the yeast
which is what we're looking for
a slow fermentation so I'm just gonna
mix this together it's gonna create a
very sticky dough so this looks good to
me now if your dough seems a little dry
you can always add a tablespoon of water
at a time until it's nice and tacky and
I can show you you should have some
dough still stuck on your fingertips and
that's how you know that this is ready
cover with plastic wrap and you're going
to let this rest at room temperature
until it doubles in bulk and it will
create lots of spongy bubbles and that's
going to take 12 to 18 hours so this is
a great recipe to make the night before
you need it so now we're going to let
rest for 12 to 18 hours here's a batch
of dough that I've made last night and
you can see it's doubled in size and
it's spongy and very very wet and this
is exactly what you're looking for and
you can smell fermentation has taken
place it has this yeasty smell and you
know that this is going to have a great
structure to it in the end so now you
need a liberally dusted work surface and
just scoop out the dough and I give a
little bit of dusting on top as well and
really all you need to do here is tuck
the edges so you're going to take your
bench scraper you're going to pull up
and push down into the middle you're
gonna repeat on the other side here
you're basically folding the dough like
a little parcel and then you're gonna
repeat with the two other edges so
folding into the center folding into the
center here I have a sheet tray lined
with parchment and dusted with flour and
gently but quickly otherwise the dough
is gonna fall all over the place get
underneath the dough and flip it right
on top now give this a good dusting of
flour as well on top of this I'm going
to use a little bit of wax paper and two
towels and this really helps to keep the
nice warm environment and this sits out
on the counter top for one and a half to
two hours until it's doubled in bulk and
when you press on the dough the dough
and bounce back it keeps or holds the
impression no if it does mount back you
just need to let it rise for about 15
more minutes and it should be good
so here we go two hours now for the fun
part the baking now to simulate a bakery
oven we are using an enameled cast iron
pot because this really does retain the
heat so I had my oven preheating to 475
degrees with the rack in the lower third
with this pot in the oven so this is
very very very hot and this is what's
going to give us that wonderful crust
that I've been talking about so remove
the towels gently remove the wax paper
so now here's the tricky part
lift the parchment up and invert this
into the bottom of your hot pot and now
you're just going to peel the parchment
up place the lid on the pot and now this
goes into the oven for about 25 minutes
then you're going to remove the cover
and bake for an extra fifteen to thirty
minutes until it's nice
dark golden brown in color it's going to
be great so the bread is hot out of the
oven it's been about thirty minutes
after taking the lid off and now a very
important step here if you want that
crisp crust that we've been talking
about you need to take it out of the pot
at this time now it should pop out
easily there we go
and now this has to cool completely and
you want to cool it on a wire rack so
that there's no steam and the bottom it
doesn't become soggy so cool it
completely before serving and I'm going
to show you what this looks like when it
is cool all right guys our bread is
completely cool I'm so excited to try
this now any combination of add-ins that
you like you can play around with this
bread if it's walnuts if it's kalamata
olives if you wanted to add some raisins
that would be great and this bread is
literally no fuss at all to make and yet
the outcome
so delicious give it a try let us know
